newsitem.title: FINLAND: Nokia, Microsoft link unlikely - analysts.
newsitem.headline: Nokia, Microsoft link unlikely - analysts.

text.p: An ownership hook-up between Finnish telecommunications group Nokia Oy and U.S. software maker Microsoft is an unlikely prospect even if it would make sense, equity analysts said on Friday.

"I wouldn't immediately believe that story," Opstock analyst Timo Nuutilainen told Reuters, when asked to comment on a report from Salomon Brothers that toyed with the idea that Microsoft might be interested in buying Nokia.
Analysts were ready to underwrite Salomon's view that a Microsoft-Nokia merger or buyout "won't happen, but it's fun to think about."

"Of course, the idea itself makes sense, and if I were Bill Gates, I'd do it," said Jukka Fransas of FSB Securities, adding: "Nokia has the wireless technology that Microsoft will need in the future."

"Microsoft is moving into new areas, and in that sense an alliance with Nokia -- or some other company with capabilities in wireless technology, such as Ericsson or Motorola would make sense," Fransas said.
"There are lots of contact points (between the technologies of the two groups)," said Jyrki Hilli of Arctos Securities.
Analysts said that while some sort of technology alliance would not be far-fetched, a buyout or a merger was unlikely.
"Nokia couldn't be had for free," one analyst said, and others said that speculative merger talk might make the Nokia share price unaffordable to any possible buyer.
"Talk like this will raise the share price," Fransas said.
